instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3536: What is 820-3536? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.R7121: What is R7121? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7105: What is R7105? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.R7122: What is R7122? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.Q7180: What is Q7180? Inrush limiter transistor that must be told by the ISL6259 that it is safe to allow charger voltage to pass through to the computer. This needs CHGR_AGATE and CHGR_SGATE to be pulled down in order for it to close and allow voltage through to the system, current sensing failures as well as ISL6259 failures can cause this to happen. .
definitions.Q7010: What is Q7010? Q7010 controls whether or not PPDCIN_G3H will be let through to the PP3V42_G3H power supply, often this circuit area is not working because D7010 has died or corroded. .
definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 No Green Light. Works on Battery.
threads.message:
computer had liquid damage
works completely fine on battery but will not power on with charger, will not charge battery
I don't see any obvious corrosion points and have finished an ultrasonic on the machine. 
I am at a loss of what to check. I know the <SIGNAL>PP18V5_DCIN</SIGNAL> is very low but cant find anything pulling it down. 


no green/orange light

Here are some measurements i took. 

pin 1 and pin 2 of j7000 pulse to 24v then drop back down to 2-3 v and orange light when testing voltage
68k resistance from pin 1 j7000

<RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR> 68k
<RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR> 101k
<RESISTOR>R7011</RESISTOR> 10k

<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> 46.9

l7095 0 


<RESISTOR>R8141</RESISTOR> 95k

pp3v42 pulsing from 100mv to 3.42v only when testing
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> missing
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 290mv
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> missing


<RESISTOR>R7116</RESISTOR> 3.02k
<RESISTOR>R7115</RESISTOR> 99.9k
<RESISTOR>R7112</RESISTOR> 1.01k
<RESISTOR>R7142</RESISTOR> 1.01k

<RESISTOR>R7110</RESISTOR> 59.3k
<RESISTOR>R7111</RESISTOR> 21.07k
<RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> 20
<RESISTOR>R7185</RESISTOR> 467k
<RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR> 10
<RESISTOR>R7122</RESISTOR> 10.2
<RESISTOR>R7180</RESISTOR> 1.29k
<RESISTOR>R7181</RESISTOR> 61.4k
<RESISTOR>R7125</RESISTOR> 0
<RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR> .01

Glad to be here i have already fixed a board going through previous topics. 
Thank you in advance.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 No Green Light. Works on Battery.
threads.message: I'd ask for resistance to ground on pins 1/2 of J7000, but my bet is <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> is bad. Do you have a donor board to swap from?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 No Green Light. Works on Battery.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 No Green Light. Works on Battery.
threads.message:
I do not have a donor board with the same <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR>, but i can order the part. 

Resistance from pin 1 to ground is 68k

2.63v on gate of <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 No Green Light. Works on Battery.
threads.message: I just pulled <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> and inspected, there was a bit of corrosion between one of the pads on the chip and the board, i cleaned and reseated, and now it is working, is this possibly a case of heating a transistor making it temporarily work or is it possible that the corrosion was the culprit?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 No Green Light. Works on Battery.
threads.message:
Turns out that was the case, as soon as the board cooled down from heating in that area, the board stopped powering. 
i have a <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> from a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> turns out it was the same component. Swapped, powers on battery is charging. This case is solved.

Thank you guys so much! i had sat this motherboard aside a couple of months ago.
